title: Can't the speed of light be measured with instruments? What is the name of that device? - Quora

response.answer_text: Agreed. Cern suggests that the limiting factor is not the speed of light but the speed of force, which determines the max velocity for all forms of propagation through space. Thinking about it as speed of force makes more sense and should open up for new ways to quantify it, for example in conjunction with studying entanglement.

No, it can’t be measured any more. It is now a defined exact quantity that serves as the standard for measurement, so it cannot itself be measured. See: Gary Novosielski's answer to Why can't we technically measure the speed of light?
A photodetector. You turn on a laser and measure how long it takes to reach the detector. Knowing the distance between the laser and the detector, you can calculate the speed of light.
It is done with a rotating mirror. The measurement method is called FOUCAULT METHOD.
